ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Spontaneous Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Leak
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by imaging (fluid in mastoid, thin tegmen tympani) and consistent with symptoms of pulsatile tinnitus, rhinorrhea, and Type C tympanogram.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vascular Disorder / AVM
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: A potential cause of pulsatile tinnitus, but ruled out by imaging (no vascular malformation or sigmoid sinus diverticulum found).

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Schwannoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to asymmetric SNHL and word recognition scores, but ruled out by MRI (no mass in IAC or CPA).

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing thresholds given reported difficulty hearing and tinnitus.
To evaluate word recognition abilities and check for retrocochlear signs (asymmetry).
To assess middle ear function, especially given the sensation of fluid and pulsatile tinnitus.
To assess the acoustic reflex pathway, though a seal could not be maintained.
MRI and CT ordered by neurotology to rule out vascular pathology or mass and investigate the source of pulsatile tinnitus.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiologic evaluation revealed bilateral asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss and word recognition scores, both significantly poorer in the right (non-tinnitus) ear. Tympanometry showed significant negative pressure (Type C) in the left ear, correlating with the patient's report of pulsatile tinnitus and rhinorrhea. Acoustic reflexes could not be measured due to seal issues.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral asymmetric SNHL. Right ear: sloping from ~30 dB HL to >90 dB HL. Left ear: sloping from ~20 dB HL to 60-70 dB HL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Asymmetric WRS. Right: 46% at 75 dB HL. Left: 72% at 68 dB HL. SRT: Right 46 dB, Left 38 dB.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear: Type C (-205 daPa). Right ear: Type A (-60 daPa).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Could not be obtained; clinician could not sustain an airtight seal in either ear.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Diagnostic imaging confirmed a spontaneous CSF leak into the left mastoid with a thin tegmen tympani. No mass or vascular malformation was found, ruling out tumor or AVM.

tests.name: Other
tests.result_summary: MRI showed fluid in left mastoid with CSF hyperintensity. CT showed mastoid opacification and very thin tegmen tympani. No mass or sigmoid sinus diverticulum.

proposed_items: Hearing instruments with active tinnitus sound generator
Otologic follow-up if changes or new symptoms occur
counseling_actions: Explanation of surgical risks (hearing loss in better ear) versus benefits

escalation.rationale_short: Referral required for medical management of pulsatile tinnitus and suspected CSF leak, and to determine surgical candidacy.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor for changes in symptoms or hearing; patient advised to seek follow-up if new symptoms occur.

expected_outcome: Patient reported continued left pulsatile tinnitus with the predictable pattern of 2-3 days on followed by 2-3 days off.
Patient remained an inconsistent hearing instrument user, although he reported he 'could barely hear' his tinnitus when wearing them.
Patient used the bedside sound conditioner infrequently.
Patient reported taking Clonazepam for sleep disturbance related to tinnitus.
Surgical intervention was denied by the neurotologist and additional ENT physicians due to the high risk of complications to the better-hearing ear.
